Stock: A share in a corporation that can be traded on a stock exchange.
All-Time High: The highest price ever reached by a security or index.
Bond: A debt agreement in which the issuer raises capital and promises interest payments and repayment of principal.
Ask: The price at which a seller is willing to sell a security.
Premium: The amount by which the price of an option exceeds its intrinsic value.
Breakout: The price moving above resistance or below support, possibly indicating a trend change.
Bear Market: A phase of falling prices and pessimistic market sentiment.
Underlying Asset: The asset on which a derivative is based, such as a stock or index.
Benchmark: A standard, such as an index, used to measure the performance of a security or fund.
Bid: The price at which a buyer is willing to purchase a security.
Black-Scholes Model: A mathematical model used to value options.
Bollinger Bands: A technical indicator measuring volatility using bands around a moving average.
Candlestick: A price chart representation showing open, close, high, and low prices.
Clearing: The process of settling and reconciling securities transactions.
CFD: Contract for Difference; a derivative allowing speculation on price movements without owning the asset.
Commodity: A raw material such as gold, oil, or wheat.
Call Option: A contract giving the right, but not the obligation, to buy a security at a set price.
Chart Analysis: The study of historical price movements to forecast future trends.
DAX: The German stock index representing major publicly traded companies.
Day Trading: Buying and selling securities within the same trading day.
Brokerage Account: An account used to hold securities and financial instruments.
Dividend: A profit distribution paid by a company to its shareholders.
Diversification: Spreading investments across assets to reduce risk.
Dow Jones: A U.S. stock index tracking 30 major industrial companies.
Elliott Wave Theory: A technical analysis method based on recurring wave patterns.
Issuer: An institution or company that issues securities.
ETF: Exchange Traded Fund; a fund traded on an exchange tracking an index or strategy.
Eurex: One of the world's largest derivatives exchanges.
Issue Price: The price at which new securities are first sold to investors.
Future: A standardized contract to buy or sell an asset at a future date and price.
Fundamental Analysis: Evaluating a security using financial and economic data.
Federal Reserve: The central banking system of the United States.
FOMC: The Federal Open Market Committee, responsible for U.S. monetary policy decisions.
Forward Contract: A customized agreement to buy or sell an asset in the future.
Fundamental Investors: Investors who base decisions on economic and financial fundamentals.
Gap: A price gap between two trading periods.
Bid Price: The price a buyer is willing to pay.
Trading Volume: The number of securities traded during a specific period.
Hedging: A strategy used to reduce risk by offsetting positions.
High-Frequency Trading: Algorithmic trading executed at extremely high speeds.
Inflation: A sustained increase in the general price level of goods and services.
Index: A measurement of the performance of a market or group of securities.
Intraday Trading: Trading that occurs within a single trading day.
IPO: Initial Public Offering; the first public sale of a company's shares.
Limit Order: An order to buy or sell a security at a specified price or better.
Long Position: Buying a security with the expectation that its price will rise.
Short Selling: Selling borrowed securities hoping to repurchase them at a lower price.
Junk Bond: A high-yield bond with low credit quality and higher risk.
Capital Market: The market for long-term financial instruments.
Knock-Out Certificate: A derivative that expires worthless if a certain price level is reached.
P/E Ratio: Price-to-Earnings ratio used to value a stock.
Correlation: A statistical measure of the relationship between variables.
Liquidity: The ability to quickly buy or sell an asset without affecting its price.
Short Interest Ratio: The percentage of shares sold short.
Long-Term Investment: An investment strategy focused on long-term growth.
Margin: Collateral required to open leveraged positions.
Market Maker: An entity providing continuous buy and sell prices.
Moving Average: An indicator that smooths price data to identify trends.
Market Order: An order to buy or sell at the current market price.
NASDAQ: A U.S. electronic stock exchange focused on technology companies.
Nominal Value: The face value of a financial instrument.
Order Book: A list of buy and sell orders for a security.
Option: A contract giving the right to buy or sell an asset.
Pips: The smallest price movement in forex trading.
Put Option: A contract giving the right to sell a security at a set price.
Portfolio: The total collection of an investor’s assets.
Primary Market: The market where new securities are issued.
Quote: The stated price to buy or sell a security.
Quantitative Easing: A monetary policy where central banks increase money supply.
Return: The profit or loss generated by an investment.
Resistance: A price level where selling pressure increases.
Risk Management: The process of identifying and controlling investment risks.
Spread: The difference between bid and ask prices.
Stop-Loss Order: An order designed to limit losses.
Support: A price level where buying pressure increases.
Swing Trading: A strategy holding positions for days or weeks.
Take-Profit Order: An order that locks in profits at a predetermined price.
Technical Analysis: Market analysis based on price and volume data.
Ticker Symbol: A unique code identifying a security on an exchange.
Trend: The general direction of price movement.
Underlying: The asset on which a derivative is based.
Volatility: The degree of price fluctuation over time.
Value Investing: An investment strategy focused on undervalued securities.
Resistance Level: A price point that limits upward movement.
Currency Risk: The risk of loss due to exchange rate changes.
Xetra: An electronic trading system operated by Deutsche Börse.
Yield: The income return on an investment.
Yield Curve: A graph showing bond yields across different maturities.
Central Bank: An institution responsible for monetary policy.
Interest Rates: The cost of borrowing or the return on lending money.
Futures Market: A market for standardized forward contracts.
